title: Study Area
text:
The primary purpose of this pilot study was to collect preliminary data to determine the potential for passive acoustic monitoring to study Ridgway’s Rails in San Diego. This pilot study was conducted in two regions: The Tijuana Estuary and the Proving Pens at the Living Coast Discovery Center. All recordings were made using Audiomoth recorders with varying settings (Recording Methods can be found here).










Recorders were attached to a post situated near a small waterway at the Tijuana Estuary. This site was located near some Ridgway’s Rails (calls were heard during our deployment, as identified by Justyn Stahl, Jeff Crooks, and Aiyana Reissman).





Audiomoth recorders attached to Solar Post near bridget at Tijuana Estuary





The Proving Pens at the Living Coast Discovery Center are used for breeding and raising young Ridgway’s Rails to support expanding the population of these endangered species. During this experiment, a breeding pair and their chicks were in Proving Pen #1 (SPP-1N), and a pair (no chicks) were in Proving Pen #3 (SPP-3S). Preliminary recordings provided high quality recordings within close proximity to known Ridgway’s Rails, proving voucher (‘ground truth’) data that can be used to improve automated detectors and validate the systems.
Additionally, we conducted an experiment to deploy recorders at distance from these known sound sources to develop a preliminary detection function to inform future survey designs.





Audiomoth recorders attached to LFRR Proving Pens at Living Coast Discovery Center










Important



Note: All results are preliminary, data were not acoustically validated!

title: Study Area
text: Recorders were attached to a post situated near a small waterway at the Tijuana Estuary. This site was located near some Ridgway’s Rails (calls were heard during our deployment, as identified by Justyn Stahl, Jeff Crooks, and Aiyana Reissman).

title: Study Area
text:
The Proving Pens at the Living Coast Discovery Center are used for breeding and raising young Ridgway’s Rails to support expanding the population of these endangered species. During this experiment, a breeding pair and their chicks were in Proving Pen #1 (SPP-1N), and a pair (no chicks) were in Proving Pen #3 (SPP-3S). Preliminary recordings provided high quality recordings within close proximity to known Ridgway’s Rails, proving voucher (‘ground truth’) data that can be used to improve automated detectors and validate the systems.
Additionally, we conducted an experiment to deploy recorders at distance from these known sound sources to develop a preliminary detection function to inform future survey designs.

title: Methods
text: Please see right-hand sidebar to navigate to specific methods.

title: Methods
text:
Study Area


This pilot study used Audiomoth recorders to monitor a single location in Tijuana River National Estuarine Research Reserve (TRNERR) as well as a series of acoustic experiments at the Ridgway Rail proving pens at the San Diego Bay National Wildlife Refuge near the Living Coast Discovery Center.
By zooming into the markers at the top of the map to see the spatial variation of the recorders at and around the proving pens.










Tijuana Estuary


Recorders were attached to a post situated near a small waterway at the Tijuana Estuary. This site was located near a calling Ridgway’s Rail (calls were heard during our deployment, as identified by Justyn Stahl, Jeff Crooks, and Aiyana Reissman).
Three Audiomoth recorders were attached to allow for three different approaches to sampling (see below for more information). The three recorders were placed vertically along the post and the microphone was directed towards the waterway (the image on the right shows the back of the audiomoths zip-tied to the post).




Audiomoth recorders attached to Solar Post near bridget at Tijuana Estuary






Living Coast Proving Pens


The Proving Pens at the Living Coast Discovery Center are used for breeding and raising young Ridgway’s Rails to support expanding the population of these endangered species. During this experiment, a breeding pair and their chicks were in Proving Pen #1 (SPP-1N), and a pair (no chicks) were in Proving Pen #3 (SPP-3S). Recordings provided high quality recordings within close proximity to known Ridgway’s Rails, proving voucher (‘ground truth’) data that can be used to improve automated detectors and validate the systems.




Audiomoth recorders attached to LFRR Proving Pens at Living Coast Discovery Center




At the Living Coast Proving Pens, We used three alternative survey designs:

Sampling Design Test: Set of 3 recorders at each proving pen to provide 3 alternative sampling designs (similar to recorders at Tijuana Estuary), see image on the right
Preliminary Detection Range Test: Single recorder at each proving pen, plus a single recorder posted 118m from SPP-1N and 87m from SPP-3S. This provided a preliminary test to determine the distribution of recorders for the subsequent survey design
Detection Range Test: The final survey design included deployment of a single recorder at SPP-1N and SPP-3S as well as 8 additional recorders deployed in the surrounding region to provide data to estimate detection range of calls attributed to the Ridgway’s Rails in the proving pens.



Deployment Table
The table below includes all audiomoth deployments for the Tijuana Estuary (TJE) and the Sweetwater Proving Pens (SPP), including the exact location (latitude, longitude), deployment and retrieval dates, and the recording configuration. Details on the recording configurations are provided below.

title: Methods
text:
Recorders
Pilot Studies use the low cost Audiomoth Recorder as temporary use of these recorders could be provided at no-cost to the pilot study. Alternatives to the Audiomoth may provide improved recording quality, longer recording durations, multiple recording sensors (for localization), or more complicated sampling options. Ultimately, identification of the most appropriate recording setup will depend on the specific study area and research needs.

Sampling Methods
The initial pilot study included 1 recording site at Tijuana Estuary (TJE), and 2 primary recording sites at the Living Coast Proving Pens (SPP-1N, SPP-3S), and each site had a set of three recorders each with different sampling regimes:



Initial Recording Specifications


Recording Type
Recording Schedule
Sampling Rate (kHz)
Record Off (s)
Record On (s)
Filter Type
High Pass Filter (kHz)
Low Pass Filter (kHz)




48continuous_def
continuous
48
00.00.05
00.00.55
NA
NA
NA


48sunrise+set_def
sunriseset
48
00.00.05
00.00.55
NA
NA
NA


192bat_def
bat
192
00.00.05
00.00.55
bandpass
12
96





Each recording configuration provided valuable information to inform future studies:

48 kHz Continuous Recording: Continuous recordings provide additional context to activities during the day and night with a trade-off between storage capacity.
48 kHz Sunrise and Sunset: Previous research suggests that Ridgway’s Rails are most vocally active during sunrise and sunset, and this more limited recording configuration allowed the recording duration to be extended. The limited recording period has reduced context, especially related to anthropogenic impacts and potential prey activity.
192 kHz Sunset to Sunrise (bat): This high frequency recording allows for detection of bat echolocation. While bat species were not the primary focus of this pilot study, they are an important species in wetland habitats and provide valuable information related to biodiversity and health of the ecosystem. Due to the high sample rate, these recordings were storage limited and of shorter duration.

title: Methods
text:
Analysis Methods

Bird Detection and Classification
Birdnet Analyzer v2.4 was used to batch analyze recordings for each deployment, with detections were saved as csv files and formatted as Raven selection tables. Settings include: Minimum confidence = .25, Sensitivity = 1, Overlap = 0, Merge consecutive detections = 1, Audo speed modification = 1, minimum bandpass = 0 Hz, Maximum bandpass = 15 kHz; species list based on location (33N, -117W) and year-round with minium occurrence probability of 0.03 for a species to be included. Detection data was output to a Raven selection table, and selection tables were combined into a single table for each recording.
Birdnet provides a confidence score associated with each detection. These scores are not probabilities but do positively relate to predication accuracy (though this relationship varies by species). Manual validation is required to translate these scores to a predication accuracy






Important



Note: All results are preliminary, data were not acoustically validated!


While this data provides sufficient preliminary recordings to allow for testing the accuracy of automated detection and classification models, this was not conducted due to time required to complete this analysis. As time allows, I intend to identify an alternative automated classifier that has a more flexible license (potentially Perch), manually validate calls, and assess the accuracy of this classifier for Ridgway’s Rails and any other target species.









Preliminary data were analyzed using R programming language and preliminary results are provided to assess the potential use of PAM for studying Ridgway’s Rails. Preliminary data products and R code are made publicly available in this repository.


Distance Sampling
A subset of data from the Detection Range Test at the Living Coast Proving Pens was manually examined to provide a preliminary estimate the detection range of Ridgway’s Rails calls from the semi-captive animals in the proving pens. This sample detection data was analyzed using the distance R package to develop a (preliminary) detection function. This data provides an initial assessment of the detection range to inform future studies.
Analysis of the entire dataset to improve the precision and accuracy of the detection function should be considered prior to implementing a proper distance sampling survey.


Bat Detection and Classification
Bats produce high frequency echolocation for communication, navigation, and foraging. Detection of these sounds requires a high sampling rate, which in turn has high storage requirements. High frequency sampling was conducted at both sites (Tijuana Estuary and the Living Coast Proving Pens), although recordings were shorter in duration.
High-frequency (192 kHz) recordings were analyzed using a trial evaluation of Kaleidoscope Pro software to detect echolocation clicks from bat species using the Western North America catalog. Again, manual analysis to evaluate the classifier performance, and all results are preliminary. To reduce the number of potentially false detections, all potential bat detections were filtered to eliminate detections with less than 10 echolocation clicks, with a high variability in species detections within events, and with species detections with low classification probabilities. While this approach likely reduces the number of false detections and inaccurate classifications, it should be considered preliminary until a thorough manual evaluation of the data can be conducted.

title: Methods
text:
Soundscape Analysis
TBD

title: Future Research
text:
Historical call-response surveys conducted since 1979 have provided a long time-series monitoring of breeding pairs of Ridgeway’s Rails in southern California. This survey design primarily relied on playback of duetting calls to elicit a response from local breeding pairs(Zembal, Hoffman, and Stahl 2024); however, specific field methods varied throughout the field season. Notably, (Thompson et al. 2024) noted that these playback methods work well when used sparingly. A recent statistical examination of call-response survey design recommended repeated sampling to decrease sampling bias(Stevens et al. 2024). While historical call-response surveys have proven to be an effective approach to monitoring Ridgeway’s Rails, recent advances in PAM monitoring using acoustic recorders may provide a more standardized approach to monitoring Ridgeway’s Rails populations that may ultimately lead to more robust estimation of population trends.


While there is great potential for using passive acoustic monitoring to assess wildlife populations, how this is done will depend on the management needs.





#| echo: false
shapefile.location <- here("data", "TJR_RB_2010.shx")
region <- make.region(region.name = "study area",
                      shape = shapefile.location)
design <- make.design(region = region, transect.type = "point", design = "random",
                      truncation = 200)
points <- generate.transects(design)
print(points)


   Strata study area:
   ___________________
Design:  randomly located transects
Number of samplers:  20
Design angle:  0
Edge protocol:  minus
Covered area:  2352730
Strata coverage: 25.36%
Strata area:  9278511

   Study Area Totals:
   _________________
Number of samplers:  20
Covered area:  2352730
Average coverage: 25.36%














Density Surface Models (dsm) for distance sampling data provide spatial models constructed from generalized additive models following methods developed by Hedley & Buckland (2004) and Miller et al. (2013).




Studies of species such as Ridgeway’s Rails benefit from the animals’ tendency to respond vocally to nearby calls. Research suggests that repeated sampling will decrease sampling bias(Stevens et al. 2024), but other research suggests that animals may habituate and render these methods futile(Zembal, Hoffman, and Stahl 2024). Call-response studies provide a measure of the number of animals in a region (abundance), but most call-response studies do not consider how variation in their sampling affects their population estimation. For example, is their ability to detect animals dependent on temporal, environmental or geographic variables? Does the call-response increase their risk by alerting predators to their location? Would an increase in sampling (to decrease bias or to improve seasonal sampling) lead to a decrease in the efficacy of sampling?
While Passive acoustic monitoring (PAM) also relies on the vocal activity of species to study their populations, it is inherently a non-invasive way to remotely sense species’ presence. It necessarily relies on the vocal behavior of these species, and therefore is more appropriate for species that can be easily detected and identified to species based on sounds that they voluntarily make. Instead of the single (or limited) call-response sampling, PAM recorders can be deployed year-round to monitor seasonal changes in vocal activity, and

Benefits and Limitations of Call-Response and PAM Sampling. Green check identifies beneficial characteristics of sampling method, and red X identifies limitation of that sampling method.







Call - Response

Passive Acoustics





High detection rate



Low detection rate

Non-invasive remote sensing




Increased sampling to reduce bias



Increased sampling to reduce bias




Animals may respond to increased sampling



No impact of increased sampling




Limited sampling to reduce habituation



Long-term sampling




































Archived data allows for replication of studies and consideration of additional studies
Soundscape monitoring provides a high-level view of changes to the environment
Effect of helicopters and other sources of anthropogenic noise on species (ADS-B or Automatic Dependent Surveillance-Broadcast), auto-detect/classify noise




Open science is a global movement to make scientific research and its outcomes freely accessible to everyone. It accelerates scientific progress and strengthens trust in research. Here are some of the many ways I intend to conduct my research in an open science framework:
Transparency:

Rely primarily (or entirely) on open source software
Make code and data products publicly available on Github

Sharing:

Make research results publicly available (Github Pages and accessible reports, publications)
Share selected audio files publicly for their use in improving AI models

Inclusivity

Identify approaches to include public participation in data collection and analysis
Seek collaborations to extend the scope of this research to take advantage of the great potential of passive acoustic data.

title: Population Assessment
text:
To date, population assessment of Ridgway’s Rails has relied on call-response survey methods conducted by an expert ornithologist. While this long time series has been highly effective, recent research suggests that repeated sampling is required to improve the robustness of the results. Unfortunately, there if evidence that this species may habituate to repeated exposure to call-response surveys, which would lead to worsened outcomes.
Distance sampling methods using visual or passive acoustic detections has proven successful for a wide range of species. Specifically, passive acoustic monitoring using acoustic recording devices placed throughout the habitat may be used as point transect or spatial capture-recapture models to assess population of cryptic species such as Ridgway’s Rails.

Detection Range
Understanding the effective detection range is fundamental to adopting distance sampling methods for population assessment. The Detection Range Test at the Living Coast Proving Pens provided an opportunity to assess the effective detection range using Audiomoth recorders in this environment. In addition to locating a recorder on each of the proving pens (which we will assume is approximately 1 meters distance from known animals), 8 additional recorders were placed at distance from the pens. This data allowed us to identify the distance at which known calls (from either SPP-1N or SPP-3S) could be detected by the Birdnet Analyzer on the Audiomoth recorders.
The map below shows the placement of the recorders on and near the pens (Click on the site to obtain the Site Code), and the table to the right shows the distance of each recorder to to the pen at SPP-01N (DD01) and SPP-03S (DD02).












Distance to Proving Pen Recorders









Distance to Site

The spectrograms on the right show a Ridgway Rail call with color representing the intensity (amplitude) of the call at the DD01 proving pen site (assumed to be at distance 0m from the source), and at a selection of sites with increasing distance from the source.
As expected, the calls of the Ridgway’s Rails are loud at the source (DD01, or proving pen SPP-01S), and the intensity of the call decreases with increasing distance, until the call can no longer be detected.




The time series, below, shows how the number of calls detected on different recorders decreases with distance from the source (DD01).









This data was then used to develop a detection function, which provides an estimate of the effective detection range for these calls. This can then be used to inform a survey design of a distance sampling approach to population assessment.









The range at which a call can be detected varies not only on the source amplitude of the call, but also the environment through which the call propagates. While the experiment at the proving pens provides an excellent preliminary estimate of detection range (and a preliminary detection function), the true detection range may vary by habitat, and the proving pens are different than typical habitat for Ridgway’s Rails. Future research should develop a detection function for Ridgway’s Rails in their preferred habitat.

title: Open Science
text:
The goal of Open Science is to ensure that science is accessible to everyone. Open Science accelerates scientific progress and strengthens trust between scientists and other communities.
The following efforts will be made to align this research with Open Science values: - Confirmed detection of species will be made publicly available - ‘Voucher’ sound samples will be made publicly available - Emphasis will be made on using open source software

title: Biodiversity
text: this is a summary of the results for the rails study from TJE

title: Passive Acoustic Pilot Study for Ridgway’s Rails
text:
The habitat of the endangered light-footed Ridgway’s rail (Rallus obsoletus levipes) includes wetlands and lagoons in southern California and northern Baja California, Mexico. This species is threatened by habitat degradation and loss, pollution, sea level rise, and non-native species.
Historical call-response surveys conducted since 1979 have provided a long time-series monitoring of breeding pairs of Ridgway’s Rails in southern California. This survey design primarily relies on playback of duetting calls to elicit a response from local breeding pairs Zembal, Hoffman, and Stahl (2024). A recent statistical examination of call-response survey design recommended repeated sampling to decrease sampling bias (Stevens et al. 2024); however, Zembal, Hoffman, and Stahl (2024) noted that these playback methods work well when used sparingly. While historical call-response surveys have proven to be an effective approach to monitoring Ridgway’s Rails, recent advances in Passive Acoustic Monitoring (PAM) using autonomous acoustic recorders may provide a more standardized approach to monitoring Ridgway’s Rails populations that may ultimately lead to more robust estimation of population trends.
This pilot study serves to identify the potential for PAM surveys as an alternative approach to monitoring the populations of Ridgway’s Rails in San Diego County. PAM has the added potential benefit of extending temporal monitoring with minimal interference during the sensitive breeding season, providing additional contextual information (anthropogenic impacts, biodiversity), and allowing for opportunities to study other local species.

Methods

Study Area
Recorders
Analysis Methods

Results

Summary
Population Assessment
Biodiversity

Future Research
Recommendations





References

Stevens, Bryan S., Courtney J. Conway, Kimberly A. Sawyer, Lauren Kershek, Giselle Block, Sandra Hamilton, and Rebecca Kolstrom. 2024. “Developing a Range-Wide Sampling Framework for Endangered Species: A Case Study with Light-Footed Ridgway’s Rail.” Biodiversity and Conservation 33 (13): 3703–26. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10531-024-02919-5.


Zembal, Richard, Susan M. Hoffman, and Justyn Stahl. 2024. “Light-Footed Ridgeway’s (Clapper) Rail in California.” https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Richard-Zembal/publication/387270261_Light-footed_Ridgway's_Clapper_Rail_in_California_2024_Season_Final_Report_to_US_Fish_and_Wildlife_Service_and_California_Department_of_Fish_and_Wildlife_Light-footed_Ridgway's_Clapper_Rail_in_Califor/links/6765c029c1b0135465eadb86/Light-footed-Ridgways-Clapper-Rail-in-California-2024-Season-Final-Report-to-US-Fish-and-Wildlife-Service-and-California-Department-of-Fish-and-Wildlife-Light-footed-Ridgways-Clapper-Rail-in-Californi.pdf.

title: Results
Summary Results
text:
Passive acoustic detection as a means of monitoring species requires that (1) the animals produce sounds that you can readily attribute to them and (2) that you have a basic understanding of the variation in both the sounds they produce and the sounds that you detect on your recorder. While their vocal behavior is well described in (cite papers), there is known variation between sites and there is great value in quantifying this variation to inform future studies.






Important



Warning: All results are preliminary, data were not acoustically validated! Need to validate recordings and assess species-specific confidence thresholds for detections



Daily Variation
There was considerable daily variation in detection of calls associated with Ridgway’s Rails at both the Proving Pens and at the Tijuana Estuary. The variation in detection of calls were similar between the recorders at the two different proving pens (not shown here). While this data is limited in scope, we do not see a strong correlation between the two sites in relation to the higher number of hours of detections. This suggests that larger environmental variables (such as moon phase or weather conditions) may not be responsible for this variation, but this may be related to site-specific variables.
This data is preliminary and has not been manually reviewed to confirm detections (add missed calls, remove false positives). Future work should include manual review of these data to ensure that calls assigned to Ridgway’s Rails are in fact calls from those species. This review will also provide a means of quantifying the accuracy (correct classification) of these models for future research.











Diurnal Variation
There is significant research suggesting that Ridgway’s Rails call more frequently during the pre-dawn and dusk time periods, and our results agree. Recordings from the Proving Pens also showed calling throughout the day and very little calling at night. Traditional call-response surveys are conducted at dusk (typically) or pre-dawn (rarely) to align with this known increase in calling behavior. Future passive acoustic surveys could limiting recording periods to one hour before/after sunrise and sunset. While this would extend the duration between recorder turnover, it would also limit additional data provided by passive acoustic monitoring that can provide information related to presence of other species, anthropogenic uses of the area, and potentially other acoustic behaviors that may occur at other times of the day.
Again, acoustic detections were not manually reviewed, and it is possible that some of these calls are actually other sounds that were attributed to this species.

title: sci-results
text:
#top 10 species- SCI
birdnet_top10_SCI <- birdnet_sci %>% 
  filter(location == "SCI") %>%
  count(common_name, sort = TRUE) %>% # Count #detections per species 
  slice_head(n = 10) %>% # Get top 10 species
  left_join(birdnet_sci, by = "common_name") # join back to original data
write_csv(birdnet_top10_SCI, here("bigData", "birdnet_top10_SCI.csv"))

title: Biodiversity
text:
Acoustic Complexity Index
The Acoustic Complexity Index (ACI) uses a linear scale of sound intensity from sound spectrograms to analyze a soundscape. It is sensitive to irregularites in the biological soundscape (and other discrete sounds) while filtering out persistant anthropogenic sounds.
cite: 10.1016/j.ecolind.2010.11.005, 10.1016/j.ecoinf.2011.07.004

# Seewave Function = "ACI"
# Build in rails_Pilot.Rmd, then output here

title: Biodiversity
text:
Acoustic Diversity Index
The Acoustic Diversity Index (ADI) uses the Shannon Index to measure the distribution of sound energy across frequency bins and was intended to serve as a proxy for habitat quality.
cite: 10.1007/s10980-011-9636-9

# Soundecology Function = "acoustic_diversity". 
# Build in rails_Pilot.Rmd, then output here

title: Biodiversity
text:
Bioacoustic Index
Intended to serve as a measure of birdsong complexity (and a proxy for relative bird abundance), it is a product of the amplitude and the number of occupied frequency bands, relative to the quietest 1 kHz frequency band.
cite:10.1890/07-0004.1

# Soundecology Function = "bioacoustic_index". 
# Build in rails_Pilot.Rmd, then output here

title: Biodiversity
text:
Acoustic Entropy Index (AEI)
The Acoustic Entropy Index is based on the entropy in both time and space (based on the Shannon Index).
cite: 10.1371/journal.pone.0004065

# Seewave Function = "H". Minimum frequency = 0 kHz, maximum frequency = Nyquist of recording, FFT = 512. 
# Build in rails_Pilot.Rmd, then output here

title: SD Wetland Dashboard
text:
Row

priority <- birdnet_all %>%
  filter(location == "TJE") %>%
  count(common_name, sort = TRUE) %>% 
  slice_head(n = 10) %>%
  pull(common_name) %>% 
  union("Ridgway's Rail") 

birdnet_top_TJE <- birdnet_all %>%
  filter(location == "TJE") %>%
  filter(common_name %in% priority)

myData_priority_TJE <- loadDetectionData(x=birdnet_top_TJE, source='csv', detectionType='detection', wide=FALSE,  tz='UTC', columnMap=list(UTC='utc', species='common_name', Latitude='latitude', Longitude='longitude'))
